easyRecg 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference

    • Sample Workflow

    easyRecg

    Installation

    You can install the development version of easyRecg from GitHub with:

    # install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("rickeycarter/easyRecg")
    library(easyRecg)
library(tibble)

    Retrieving 12-lead data

    A matrix with data for 12-leads can be generated using the function read_muse_xml_ecg:

    # Get sample file
file1 <- ecg_example("muse/muse_ecg1.xml")

# Read xml file - return a 2d matrix
ecg1_2d <- read_muse_xml_ecg(file1, numpyformat = F)

dim(ecg1_2d)
#> [1] 5000   12

head(ecg1_2d)
#>        I  II III  aVR aVL aVF V1  V2  V3  V4  V5  V6
#> [1,] 156 214  58 -185  48 136 68 204 390 312 165 126
#> [2,] 156 214  58 -185  48 136 68 204 390 312 165 126
#> [3,] 156 214  58 -185  48 136 68 204 390 312 165 126
#> [4,] 156 214  58 -185  48 136 68 204 390 312 165 126
#> [5,] 165 219  53 -192  56 136 68 219 400 322 175 131
#> [6,] 165 224  58 -195  53 141 68 224 409 331 185 136

# Instead, return a 4d array formatted for AI inputs
ecg1_4d <- read_muse_xml_ecg(file1, numpyformat = T)

dim(ecg1_4d)
#> [1]    1 5000   12    1

    A directory of ecg files can be read and returned as an array using the read_muse_xml_directory function:

    # Sample directory of muse files
muse_dir <- system.file("extdata", path = "muse", package = "easyRecg")

# Check number of files 
length(dir(muse_dir))
#> [1] 3

# Read xml files
all_muse <- read_muse_xml_directory(muse_dir)
#> A total of  3  ecgs were located.  Preparing to read.
#> ECGs successfully read.  Returned object includes numeric array and listing of files in the order of the array.

names(all_muse)
#> [1] "ecg_array"   "array_order"
dim(all_muse$ecg_array)
#> [1]    3 5000   12    1

    Retrieving ECG Meta Data

    By default, read_muse_xml_meta returns all meta data available. The returned object is a named list of data frames (or tibbles). The function can take a file path or a collection of file paths. If more than one file path is present, the results are appended together.

    meta1 <- read_muse_xml_meta(file1, ids = 1)
meta1
#> $muse_info
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 2
#>      id muse_version
#>   <dbl> <chr>       
#> 1     1 9.0.9.18167 
#> 
#> $patient_demographics
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 6
#>      id patient_id patient_age age_units gender patient_last_name
#>   <dbl> <chr>      <chr>       <chr>     <chr>  <chr>            
#> 1     1 JAX01234   60          YEARS     MALE   TEST 05          
#> 
#> $test_demographics
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 24
#>      id data_type site  site_name acquisition_device status    edit_list_status
#>   <dbl> <chr>     <chr> <chr>     <chr>              <chr>     <chr>           
#> 1     1 RESTING   11    Research  MAC55              CONFIRMED Confirmed       
#> # â€¦ with 17 more variables: priority <chr>, location <chr>,
#> #   location_name <chr>, acquisition_time <chr>, acquisition_date <chr>,

    Customizing Output Results

    In some cases, you may not want all data returned (e.g.Â to avoid sharing PHI). To do so, you can take a whitelisting, blacklisting, or mixed approach.

    Whitelisting

    To include only certain data sets or columns, you can specify a named list of dataframes and columns. If a named element is NA, all variables from that dataset are returned.

    Here, we will return only muse data, patient id and age, and test date.

    include <- list(
  muse_info = NA,
  patient_demographics = c("patient_id", "patient_age", "age_units"),
  test_demographics = "acquisition_date"
)

read_muse_xml_meta(file1, include = include, id = 1)
#> $muse_info
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 2
#>      id muse_version
#>   <dbl> <chr>       
#> 1     1 9.0.9.18167 
#> 
#> $patient_demographics
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 4
#>   patient_id patient_age age_units    id
#>   <chr>      <chr>       <chr>     <dbl>
#> 1 JAX01234   60          YEARS         1
#> 
#> $test_demographics
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 2
#>   acquisition_date    id
#>   <chr>            <dbl>
#> 1 05-10-2021           1

    Blacklisting

    Similar to whitelisting, you can specifiy specific data sets or elements to exclude. Here, if a named element is NA, the entire dataset is removed.

    Letâ€™s remove all resting ecg data along with patient names:

    exclude <- list(
  resting_ecg_measurements = NA,
  original_resting_ecg_measurements = NA,
  patient_demographics = c("patient_last_name")
)

read_muse_xml_meta(file1, exclude = exclude, ids = 1)
#> $muse_info
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 2
#>      id muse_version
#>   <dbl> <chr>       
#> 1     1 9.0.9.18167 
#> 
#> $patient_demographics
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 5
#>      id patient_id patient_age age_units gender
#>   <dbl> <chr>      <chr>       <chr>     <chr> 
#> 1     1 JAX01234   60          YEARS     MALE  
#> 
#> $test_demographics
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 24
#>      id data_type site  site_name acquisition_device status    edit_list_status
#>   <dbl> <chr>     <chr> <chr>     <chr>              <chr>     <chr>           
#> 1     1 RESTING   11    Research  MAC55              CONFIRMED Confirmed       
#> # â€¦ with 17 more variables: priority <chr>, location <chr>,
#> #   location_name <chr>, acquisition_time <chr>, acquisition_date <chr>,
#> #   cart_number <chr>, acquisition_software_version <chr>,
#> #   analysis_software_version <chr>, edit_time <chr>, edit_date <chr>,
#> #   overreader_id <chr>, editor_id <chr>, overreader_last_name <chr>,
#> #   overreader_first_name <chr>, editor_last_name <chr>,
#> #   editor_first_name <chr>, his_status <chr>
#> 
#> $diagnosis
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 8
#>      id modality diagnosis_statement_stmt_flag diagnosis_stateâ€¦ diagnosis_stateâ€¦
#>   <dbl> <chr>    <chr>                         <chr>            <chr>           
#> 1     1 RESTING  ENDSLINE                      Statement Text(â€¦ ENDSLINE        
#> # â€¦ with 3 more variables: diagnosis_statement_stmt_text_2 <chr>,
#> #   diagnosis_statement_stmt_flag_3 <chr>,
#> #   diagnosis_statement_stmt_text_3 <chr>
#> 
#> $original_diagnosis
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 8
#>      id modality diagnosis_statement_stmt_flag diagnosis_stateâ€¦ diagnosis_stateâ€¦
#>   <dbl> <chr>    <chr>                         <chr>            <chr>           
#> 1     1 RESTING  ENDSLINE                      Statement Text(â€¦ ENDSLINE        
#> # â€¦ with 3 more variables: diagnosis_statement_stmt_text_2 <chr>,
#> #   diagnosis_statement_stmt_flag_3 <chr>,
#> #   diagnosis_statement_stmt_text_3 <chr>
#> 
#> $qrs_times_types
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 33
#>      id qrs_number qrs_type qrs_time qrs_number_2 qrs_type_2 qrs_time_2
#>   <dbl> <chr>      <chr>    <chr>    <chr>        <chr>      <chr>     
#> 1     1 1          0        808      2            0          1810      
#> # â€¦ with 26 more variables: qrs_number_3 <chr>, qrs_type_3 <chr>,
#> #   qrs_time_3 <chr>, qrs_number_4 <chr>, qrs_type_4 <chr>, qrs_time_4 <chr>,
#> #   qrs_number_5 <chr>, qrs_type_5 <chr>, qrs_time_5 <chr>, qrs_number_6 <chr>,
#> #   qrs_type_6 <chr>, qrs_time_6 <chr>, qrs_number_7 <chr>, qrs_type_7 <chr>,

#>   <dbl> <chr>              <chr>                 <chr>            <chr>         
#> 1     1 1000               SCD06526477PA1005202â€¦ 1000             SCD06526477PA

    Mixed filtering

    If you want more flexibility but donâ€™t want to type out all names/variables, you can use both include and exclude. The same logic above applies here, however the include is always executed first.

    Here, we will return all patient demographics except name:

    # Only consider the patient demographics
include <- list(patient_demographics = NA)

# Remove patient name
exclude <- list(patient_demographics = c("patient_last_name"))

read_muse_xml_meta(file1, include = include, exclude = exclude, ids = 1)
#> $patient_demographics
#> # A tibble: 1 Ã— 5
#>      id patient_id patient_age age_units gender
#>   <dbl> <chr>      <chr>       <chr>     <chr> 
#> 1     1 JAX01234   60          YEARS     MALE

    Data Sources

    ECG XML files included in this package are simulated and do not represent actual patient evaluations.
